I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  To address worsening urban transport problems, the Government of the Philippines has 
developed its National Environmentally Sustainable Transport Strategy, which includes Davao 
as one of the focus cities.1 Extensive consultation has occurred between the government and 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) under the ADB-supported Promoting Sustainable Urban 
Transport in Asia Project, which included Davao as one of the three case study cities.2 The 
study of Davao, completed in July 2011, recommended addressing the urgent requirement to 
modernize the city’s public transport system and operations. In line with this recommendation, 
ADB fielded a reconnaissance mission to Davao on 12–13 July 2012 to discuss with government 
officials  urban  transport  issues  and  reach  agreement  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of policy and 
advisory technical assistance (TA) for the Davao Sustainable Urban Transport Project. The TA is 
included in ADB’s 2012–2014 country operations business plan for the Philippines.3 The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Strong economic growth has generated rapidly growing demand for travel within urban 
centers such as Davao. Worsening congestion, higher travel times and costs, deteriorating local 
air quality, and a failing road safety record are all symptoms of a transport system under 
pressure. Sustainable urban transport systems have modern, efficient, and affordable public 
transport services  at their  core.  Public  transport  is the main  mode  of  transport  in  Davao, 
accounting for 80% of trips. The public transport system has tricycles primarily for short trips 
and jeepneys, or multi-cab vehicles5 for longer distances within the city. Regulations governing 
Davao’s public transport system are outdated, the city lacks an effective transport masterplan, 
and institutions responsible for managing urban transport presently do not coordinate their 
planning and enforcement. Current public transport routes, the coverage area, connectivity, and 
the frequency of service are poorly planned and fail to provide satisfactory service. 
 
3.  Davao urgently needs to modernize its public transport operations so that they can serve 
as the backbone of the transport area for the greater metropolitan area. Modernizing Davao’s 
public transport system will alleviate congestion and reduce high travel costs. A prerequisite for 
future urban transport improvements in the city over the medium- to long-term is to provide 
policy and advisory support to rationalize public transport routing and franchising mechanisms, 
toward ensuring that services meet demand for travel across the city. 
 
4.  The government recognizes that upgrading and improving the operational efficiency of 
the public transport system in Davao is an urgent priority to ensure the continued economic 
vitality of the city and support inclusive development for all its citizens. Public transport is the 
mode of transport for the poor and others without access to private vehicles. These are, thus, 
captive users. The government understands that reforms to policy, institutions, governance, and

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  The policy and advisory TA will help the government to create an enabling environment 
for a modern, efficient, and affordable public transport system in Davao that can then be 
presented for demonstration and replication across the Philippines. The TA will prepare plans 
and franchising mechanisms to improve the integration of the public transport system, widen the 
coverage area, and deliver more efficient transport services to passengers in Davao. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  The TA  has four  outputs: (i) the  development  of  a  comprehensive  public  transport 
strategy for Davao, (ii) the development of a public transport reform program, (iii) a capacity 
development, and (iv) stakeholder consultation program. 
 
7.  Key activities will include assessing the current status of public transport in Davao. 
Current public transport service provision will be analyzed in terms of coverage area, fare 
structures, daily operating hours, vehicle fleets, and users’ perception of services. From this 
background assessment, a strategic policy document will be prepared that will outline the key 
performance  indicators  (KPIs)  for  an  integrated,  modern,  efficient,  and  affordable  public 
transport system. The policy document will be supported by a detailed reform program and 
implementation plans for revising and modernizing the public transport system’s coverage area 
and  route  network,  amending  franchising  mechanisms  and  bidding  procedures,  assessing 
network coverage, and developing an expansion program. The work will generate guidelines 
toward integrating fares and providing through-ticketing for trips requiring transfers. The TA will 
have a substantial capacity development component to train government officials and public 
transport  owners  and  operators.  A  number  of  community  outreach  events  will  ensure  the 
broadest possible stakeholder participation in developing the city transport system. Outreach 
meetings  will  ensure  that  all  affected  social  groups,  government  officials,  public  transport 
owners and operators, and passengers are able to contribute to the discussion of the issues 
and proposed changes to improve services. This approach has proven to be a vitally important 
aspect of public transport improvement; all stakeholders must take part in decision-making to 
ensure  that  suitable  and  sustainable  solutions  are  developed  and  implemented  and  are 
acceptable to end users. 
 
8.  The development of the comprehensive public transport strategy will include a thorough 
review of city development plans, including the urban masterplan and any transport plans for the 
city.6 The review will include analyses of the policy, legal, and regulatory framework governing 
public transport operations and franchising mechanisms, as well as a review of current public 
transport operations, including the coverage area, route network, fare structure and collection 
mechanisms, and the organizational structures of service providers. Public transport service 
providers’  organizations  and  structures  will  be  assessed,  along  with  information  on  their 
respective  revenues,  operating  costs,  assets,  budgets,  and  accounting  and  financial 
management  systems  and  practices,  to  fully  understand  the  financial  performance  of  the 
subsector.  Existing  and  proposed  public  transport  facilities  will  be  inventoried,  including 
                                                
6  City Government of Davao. 2010. Metro Davao Urban Transport Study. Davao.

3 
terminals and bus stops. Key external and internal stakeholders for public transport will be 
identified and their roles analyzed. The information will be used to prepare a comprehensive 
public transport strategy that defines KPIs for service provision. 
 
9.  The public transport reform program will formulate a policy document governing public 
transport operations and their coverage area. It will define public transport system operations 
and specifications, prepare a route network and service provision plan, and develop public 
transport franchising mechanisms and a bidding process. System integration mechanisms and 
policy  guidelines  will  be  prepared  for  the  subsector  with  linked  monitoring,  policing,  and 
enforcement guidelines. 
 
10.  The capacity development component will (i) prepare a training program for government 
officials and public transport owners and operators on public transport route planning and 
franchising  mechanisms,  (ii)  develop  training  materials  on  policing  and  enforcement  and 
undertake initial training, and (iii) develop a program and training modules to enhance public 
transport operators’ financial management and operational efficiency. Extensive stakeholder 
consultations undertaken throughout the project will ensure that the proposed structure for 
public transport reform is widely supported, especially by passengers and civil society groups. 
The  findings  of  the  TA  will  be  made  available  to  the  Department  of  Transportation  and 
Communication (DOTC) for replication in other cities across the country to improve public 
transport systems and services. 
 
11.  As the TA is likely to affect current operators and passengers, the capacity development 
and stakeholder consultation program will ensure that all social impacts of the project are 
adequately addressed. The TA will work closely with assistance for non-motorized transport 
now under consideration for Davao.7 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,250,000, of which $1 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation  and 
equipment,  venues for workshops  and seminars,  and  other  in-kind  contributions. The  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. The government has been informed that the 
implementation of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. Disbursements 
under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The TA will provide advisory services to the government and to the  city of Davao 
regarding the program to modernize public transport. The executing agency will be the DOTC 
and the implementing agency will be the city government of Davao. Capacity development will 
be provided to staff of the executing and implementing agency alike. TA collaboration will be 
managed by a steering committee established under the TA to ensure that the development and 
pilot testing of public transport reforms for Davao can be replicated across the Philippines under 
the guidance of DOTC.

14.  The key outcome of the TA is the design of a public transport reform and modernization 
program. The project will be implemented over 12 months from November 2012 to November 
2013. Consultancy services will be provided by a firm. The TA will require 20 person-months of 
international  consultancy  and  40  person-months  of  national,  providing  expertise  in  public 
transport, franchising mechanisms, transport planning, capacity development, and financing and 
bidding documentation. Consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Consulting services will be 
provided by a firm selected using the quality- and cost-based method with a standard quality–
cost  ratio  of  80:20  and  simplified  technical  proposals.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants is in Appendix 3. 
 
15.  Reports will be prepared for each of the main outputs: (i) a report of the review of current 
public transport system operations and services; (ii) a comprehensive public transport strategy 
for  Davao;  (iii)  a  report  covering  the  public  transport  reform  program,  incorporating  route 
structure, operation requirements, KPIs, and an implementation guideline and schedule; and (iv) 
a  report  describing  a  capacity  development  and  stakeholder  consultation  program  for 
government officials, public transport operators, civil society organizations such as the taxi 
operators and drivers associations and the jeepney operators and drivers associations, and 
community members. Several workshops and training sessions held during the TA will ensure 
broad stakeholder involvement and capacity development. The workshops and training sessions 
will be administered by the consultant team with funding from the TA. The findings of the study 
will be widely disseminated at national and international events and through the ADB website. 
 
16.  As the implementing agency, the city of Davao will ensure the availability of (i) all 
relevant documents, data, and any other information that may be required by the TA consultants 
to meet the objectives of the TA; (ii) appropriate and qualified counterpart staff and secretarial 
and  clerical  support;  (iii)  suitable  office  accommodation  and  equipment;  and  (iv)  logistical 
assistance for the workshops and seminars to prepare the venue, identify and invite participants, 
provide secretarial services and seminar coordination. 
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of the Philippines to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for the Davao Sustainable Urban Transport Project, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope and Outcomes  
 
1.  The policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) will provide advisory services to the 
government and to the city of Davao toward a program to modernize public transport. The 
Department of Transportation and Communications will be the executing agency for the TA and 
the city government of Davao will be the implementing agency. The outcome of the TA is to 
improve the integration of the city’s public transport system, broaden its coverage area, and 
enhance efficient services for passengers. 
 
2.  The key output of the TA is the design and implementation of a public transport strategy 
and an associated reform and modernization program. The reform program will define public 
transport routes and services, the coverage area, and hours and frequency of operations. The 
services will be delivered through the implementation of a new franchising mechanism driven by 
performance indicators to ensure passenger satisfaction. The program will bring about system 
integration and enhanced enforcement to carry efficiencies over into operations. The project will 
build  on  previous  work  such  as  that  undertaken  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  for  the 
Implementation of Asian City Transport–Promoting Sustainable Urban Transport in Asia Project1 
and  review  current  public  transport  operations  and  services,  including  regulatory  and 
operational conditions. The TA will include a substantial capacity development program and 
stakeholder participation program for government officials, public transport operators, and civil 
society to ensure the broadest support for public transport modernization. 
 
3.  Reports will be prepared for each of the main outputs: (i) a report on the review of 
current public transport operations and services; (ii) a comprehensive public transport strategy 
for  Davao;  (iii)  a  report  covering  the  public  transport  reform  program,  incorporating  route 
structure, operation requirements, key performance indicators, and an implementation guideline 
and  schedule;  and  (iv)  a  capacity  development  and  stakeholder  participation  program  for 
government officials, public transport operators, and civil society. 
 
4.  The project is expected to cost $1.0 million. The consultancy will be implemented over 
12  months,  with  services  provided  by  a  firm.  The  TA  will  require  20  person-months  of 
international  consultancy  and  40  person-months  of  national.  The  workshops  and  training 
sessions will be administered by the consultant team with funding from the TA. 
 
B.  Tasks 
 
5.  The consulting firm will produce a review of current public transport operations and 
services in Davao and develop a comprehensive public transport strategy for the city. It will 
design  a  public  transport  reform  program  including  capacity  development  and  stakeholder 
participation. 
 
6.  The firm will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Review  the  existing  urban  masterplan  and transport strategy for  Davao,  the 
Metro Davao Urban Transport Study, and provide a strategic assessment of 
updates required for the transport system as a whole covering all modes of 
transport and infrastructure and system improvements required, if any, to ensure

operations  and franchising  mechanisms  in  the Philippines  and  particularly  in 
Davao,  and  identify  any  issues  that  may  hinder  efficient  public  transport 
operations. 
(iii)  Review and report on current public transport operations in Davao, including 
coverage area, route network, frequency of services, fare structure and collection 
mechanisms, and service providers’ organizational structure. 
(iv)  Document the existing public transport fleet and suggest improvements to the 
fleet required for efficient operations.  
(v)  Review  public  transport  service  providers’  finances,  including  revenues, 
operating costs, and assets. 
(vi)  Review  public  transport  operators’  budgeting,  accounting,  and  financial

(ix)  Identify key external and internal stakeholders in public transport.

performance indicators for service provision and operation.

area.

(xiii)  Prepare a route network and service provision plan that takes into account new

7.  Toward providing 20 person-months of international consultancy and 40 person-months 
of national, the consulting firm will require the following specialists. 
 
1.  Public  Transport  Specialist  and  Team  Leader  (international,  12  person-
months)  
 
8.  The public transport specialist must have at least 15 years’ relevant experience in areas 
relating to public transport planning, operations, and performance evaluation, at least 10 years

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
of which should be appropriate international experience, preferably in a developing economy. 
He or she must have a master’s or equivalent degree in transport or a related field. He or she 
will be the team leader for the TA and provide technical expertise and the project management 
and supervision required to manage a team of international and national experts. Specific areas 
of responsibility for the public transport specialist will include the development of the public 
transport strategy and associated activities and the development of the public transport reform 
program. He or she will assist in developing the capacity development program and stakeholder 
participation program. 
 
2.  Franchising  and/or  Public–Private  Partnership  Specialist  (international,  2 
person-months) 
 
9.  The financial and/or public–private partnership specialist should have experience in the 
development  and  implementation  of  performance-based  contracting,  preferably  for  public 
transport. He or she should have extensive working knowledge of the financial management of 
public  transport.  He  or  she  should  have  a  proven  track  record  of  working  in  developing 
economies. Specific areas of responsibility include the review of the current policy, legal, and 
regulatory framework for public transport operations and franchising, the review of the public 
transport  operators’  finances,  and  the  development  of  the  public  transport  franchising 
mechanisms and bidding process, including the integration mechanisms and guidelines. He or 
she will be responsible for the workshops and consultation with stakeholders in areas related to 
franchising and bidding procedures for the proposed franchising mechanisms.  
 
3.  Transport Planner (international, 4 person-months) 
 
10.  The transport planner should have at least 10 years’ professional experience in urban 
transport planning, preferably in public transport planning. He or she should have expertise in 
route networks and operations for urban public transport. He or she should have at least 5 years 
of international experience, some in a developing economy. The transport planner will assist the 
public transport specialist in assessing public transport policy and developing a strategy to 
improve it. He or she will take responsibility for reviewing public transport system operations, 
including  coverage  area,  time  of  operations,  fare  structures,  and  route  network,  and  for 
assessing associated public transport facilities such as terminals and proposing improvements. 
He or she will be responsible for ensuring that the public transport strategy aligns with the 
broader transport strategy for the city. 
 
4.  Capacity  Development  and  Training  Specialist  (international,  2  person-
months) 
 
11.  The  capacity  development  and  training  specialist  must  have  qualifications  in  the 
development  and  delivery  of  training  programs,  preferably  for  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises and in developing economies. He or she should hold a suitable master’s degree and 
have  worked  in  developing  economies.  The  capacity  development  specialist  will  assist  in 
assessing the needs of key stakeholder groups and be responsible for delivering capacity 
development and training programs.  
 
5.  Public Transport Specialist (national, 12 person-months)  
 
12.  The public transport specialist should have over 15 years of relevant experience and an 
extensive understanding of the public transport system in the Philippines. He or she will be the 
deputy team leader. He or she should hold a master’s degree in a subject related to transport

Appendix 3  11 
and have worked previously with international development organizations on transport projects. 
He or she will assist in the areas of public transport system operations and improvements and 
be active in engaging public transport operators and government counterparts, especially during 
workshops, stakeholder meetings, and capacity development sessions. 
 
6.  Transport Planner (national, 12 person-months)  
 
13.  The  transport  planner  must  have  over  5  years  of  relevant  experience  and  hold  a 
master’s degree in a transport-related subject. He or she should have previously worked with 
international development organizations on transport projects. The transport planner will assist 
the transport  elements of the  project  and  in  particular  determine  how  the  public transport 
strategy and reform program integrate with broader transport systems and operations in Davao. 
He or she will assist with the outreach and capacity development program and workshops.  
 
7.  Financial and Bid Documentation Specialist (national, 2 person-months) 
 
14.  The  financial  and  bid  documentation  specialist  should  have  a  master’s  degree  or 
equivalent in a related field and preferably have work experience with international development 
organizations. The specialist will assist in evaluating current public transport operators’ finances 
and  provide  input  on  the  financial  and  bidding  requirements  under  Philippine  law  for  the 
proposed public transport reform program. 
 
8.  Capacity Development and Training Specialist (national, 6 person-months) 
 
15.  The capacity development and training specialist should have a strong track record in 
developing  and  implementing  capacity  development  programs,  both  for  large  government 
institutions and for small and medium-sized enterprises. He or she should have previously 
worked  with  international  development  organizations.  He  or  she  will  be  responsible  for 
organizing and running the capacity development training programs. 
 
9.  Stakeholder Participation Specialist (national, 8 person-months) 
 
16.  The stakeholder participation specialist should have a strong track record in stakeholder 
involvement, both in large government institutions and in civil society. He or she should have 
experience in broad stakeholder involvement exercises and group-sourcing techniques. He or 
she will be responsible for developing the stakeholder communication and outreach plan and for 
organizing and running the stakeholder meeting program.
